Installed as Prime Minister by General Suchinda after a coup. Focused on deregulation, cutting red tape, and fostering free enterprise. Improved relations with Laos, Cambodia, and Vietnam, but faced criticism for a soft stance towards Burma's military junta.
Second term as Prime Minister of Thailand
Invited to serve as Prime Minister after military take-over in February 1991

career_events.role: Chairman of the Board of Directors

career_events.description: Led administration focused on reforms in education, public health, exports, agriculture, industry, environment, and living conditions. Implemented significant taxation reforms, including VAT introduction and corporate tax reduction. Oversaw infrastructure projects and established regulatory board for privatization. Increased wages for civil servants and minimum wage. Allocated budget for village discretionary spending. Key accomplishments include ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA), anti-AIDS/HIV policy, and electricity market reform.
Rejoined as chairman after the 1992 general elections, resigned in 2002.
Returned to the private sector and engaged in public service activities, including chairing the constitution drafting committee.
Awarded an Honorary Degree of Doctor of Social Sciences honoris causa.

career_events.role: Member and Chairman of the Drafting Committee
career_events.description: Oversaw the drafting of the 'Peoples' Constitution' of 1997, which included reforms such as decentralization of government, establishment of independent agencies, and mechanisms to increase political stability.
Elected to the Thai Constitution Drafting Assembly and appointed Chairman, leading to the successful ratification of the new Constitution.

Appointed by President François Mitterrand, introduced and passed the bill to abolish the death penalty in France, abolished special courts, and improved victims' rights.
Abolished the death penalty in 1981, revised the criminal code, and established measures to reinforce individual and victim rights.
Presented and pushed through the law removing the death penalty, earning the nickname 'Monsieur Abolition'. Also decriminalized homosexual relations and ended special military courts.
Began government career in 1981
Appointed as President of the Constitutional Council after resigning as Minister of Justice.
Reviewed French law to ensure alignment with the constitution.
